reporting-org.narrative: European Centre for Development Policy Management (ECDPM)

title.narrative: 11. Financing for Sustainable Development: Smart (public and private) development finance

description.narrative: This work stream mainly contributes to the overall ECDPM impact areas to “Effective international cooperation frameworks and tools for tackling global challenges”, as well as “Legitimate and accountable public institutions” and “sustainable economic transformation” More specifically changes that are desired are therefore that:1) European financing for development is less fragmented and more coherent in its approach to the SDGs; in particular, International and Development Financing institutions (IFIs/DFIs), including development banks, and European ones in particular (EIB, EDFI, EBRD) are better connected and integrated in development cooperation tools of EU donors (i.e. among DFIs, DFI-donor agency, and at EU level) to foster the 2030 Agenda, including blending mechanisms to combine public and private resources.2) This would mean that a more coherent approach is taken at the European level to foster investment for greater development impact and harness risk mitigation mechanisms along the SDGs and to link European approaches to African ones, in an effort to also attract long term finance (i.e. mainly institutional financiers).3) Climate finance and other vertical funds are more effectively mobilised and enhance climate finance readiness (defined as the capacities of countries to plan for, access, deliver, and monitor and report on climate finance, both international and domestic, in ways that are catalytic and fully integrated with national development policies and the achievement of the SDGs), in particular for African countries, with the support of MDBs and DFIs (including African ones).

Biennial outcome narrative by ECDPM assessing the progress made towards the envisaged outcomes in the period: 2017-01-01 - 2019-03-31

title.narrative: Qualitative indicator

comment.narrative: ECDPM reports biennially on its outcomes in a narrative

1. Contextualisation and importance With the 2030 Agenda and Addis Ababa Action Agenda, greater attention is put on sustainable growth and private investment to achieve the SDGs. For development cooperation actors, one of the challenges is thus how best to leverage private finance for sustainable and inclusive development objectives, scaling up the volume and improving the effectiveness of blended finance, including public-private partnerships, notably in poorer and more fragile contexts. This has also become a major issue for the EU, which has been engaged in rethinking its financing architecture to that effect, as exemplified by its External Investment Plan. It also includes renewed attention to the roles and impacts of European Development Finance Institutions (DFIs) and Multilateral Development Banks (MDBs), such as the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), as well as the World Bank Group/IFC and African Development Bank. 2. Contributions made to the main changes envisaged 1) European financing for development is less fragmented and more coherent in its approach to the SDGs; in particular, International and Development Financing institutions (IFIs/DFIs), including development banks, and European ones in particular (EIB, EDFI, EBRD) are better connected and integrated in development cooperation tools of EU donors (i.e. among DFIs, DFI-donor agency, and at EU level) to foster the 2030 Agenda, including blending mechanisms to combine public and private resources Blended finance is the strategic use of development finance for the mobilisation of additional finance towards sustainable development in developing countries (OECD definition) and as such is a key means of implementation to achieve the SDGs. Yet, the challenge is to ensure that blended finance constitute an appropriate and effective use of public development finance, in the broader context of finance for development. In this respect, there is a range of experiences among financial institutions, in Europe and beyond. Our work has been to contribute to a more coherent and effective approach to blended finance. We have engaged at two levels: international level and the European level. On the international dimension, we have been an active member of the OECD-led Senior Advisory Group on blended finance, establishing a close cooperation with the OECD Secretariat and participating to OECD Coordination Meetings on advancing the Joint Agenda on Blended Finance (in Paris and Washington DC). This OECD-led international effort has led to the adoption in early 2018 of the OECD DAC Blended Finance Principles (http://www.oecd.org/development/financing-sustainable-development/blended-finance-principles/) and in October 2018 to the adoption of the Tri Hita Karana Roadmap for Blended Finance (http://www.oecd.org/dac/financing-sustainable-development/development-finance-topics/Tri-Hita-Karana-Roadmap-for-Blended-Finance.htm), which highlight shared values and action plan. ECDPM is also contributing to the development of OECD guidance on better practices to implement the blended finance principles, focusing on the blended finance principle on local context and ownership. In doing so, we are in contact with many MDBs and international think tanks. On the European dimension, ECDPM has liaised with the key institutional actors involved in the European financing for external investment, including the European Commission, the European External Action Service, the European Parliament, some EU Member States, European Development Finance Institutions (DFIs), the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), Agence française de développement (AFD) and KfW, as well as the World Bank Group. We have organised or contributed to numerous closed-door and public events and briefings, conducted some related training for European officials, and produced several publications. 2) This would mean that a more coherent approach is taken at the European level to foster investment for greater development impact and harness risk mitigation mechanisms along the SDGs and to link European approaches to African ones, in an effort to also attract long term finance (i.e. mainly institutional financiers) The EU initiative to set up an External Investment Plan (EIP) is an ambitious one. While building on the European experience, notably with Blending Facilities (on financing) and Budget Support (on investment climate), the EIP aims to contribute towards a more coherent EU financing architecture for external investment. ECDPM has been closely informing and facilitating the discussion and policy elaboration around development finance instruments. Our work has focused on drawing some of the lessons from the existing EU blended finance instruments for the EIP, notably in access to energy, working together with partners and bringing key stakeholders together, and documenting key lessons. We have provided technical input in the context of the adoption of the European Fund for Sustainable Development (EFSD) Regulation, contribute to the debate with the European Parliament, some Member States, DFIs and MDBs. In a set of two briefing notes, we untangled what the European External Investment Plan is really about as well as pointing out some of its current challenges that need to be addressed to make it a game changer for sustainable development. The 2018 spring issue of our quarterly ‘Great Insights’ magazine also covered the challenges in development finance from different angles. In doing so, we have also contributed to the discussion on the EU partnership with Africa, highlighting the need to focus on financing for sustainable investment for decent job creation (in two briefing notes, as a member of the European Think Tank Group) as well as the need to more closely associate African actors in the EU endeavours to reshape its financial instruments for external investment (in events and publications). This work has been further elaborated in our input on the debate towards the new EU Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and the Commission proposal to set up an open system of guarantees of up to €60 billion with an enhanced European Fund for Sustainable Development (the EFSD+). 3) Climate finance and other vertical funds are more effectively mobilised and enhance climate finance readiness (defined as the capacities of countries to plan for, access, deliver, and monitor and report on climate finance, both international and domestic, in ways that are catalytic and fully integrated with national development policies and the achievement of the SDGs), in particular for African countries, with the support of MDBs and DFIs (including African ones) ECDPM work so far has focused on stressing the sustainability dimension of financing approaches, stressing the need for more ambitious agenda and targets, and comprehensive approaches, notably in the areas of access to energy and agriculture. We have also developed two main projects which will directly address the climate dimension of sustainable financing: 1) in the context of the EU Horizon 2020 research project on climate change from a European perspective, ECDPM will focus on the strategies and actions of European MDBs and DFIs towards climate finance; 2) in the context of our work on regional value chains in agriculture, we will also focus on approaches to more effectively finance climate smart agriculture. 3. Did you consider gender issues during the process of engagement? In the context of our work on the EIP and EFSD+, ECDPM has stressed the need to more explicitly include the gender dimension. The key role of women has also been highlighted in articles we published on blended finance, illicit financial flows, gender budgeting, private sector investment and job creation.
